topic_knowledge_points: A stack is a LIFO container where insertion and deletion occur at the top using push, pop, and top with size and empty as accessors.
The STL stack is a templated adapter (typically over vector) providing push, pop, top, size, and empty but leaves behavior undefined on empty access.
A stack interface specifies size, empty, top, push, and pop with exceptions on empty access for top and pop.
An array-based stack maintains an array S and a top index t with all operations running in O(1) time and fixed capacity.
A linked-list stack uses a singly linked list with the head as the top to provide O(1) push, pop, and top without fixed capacity.
Stacks can be applied to reverse a sequence by pushing all elements then popping back in reverse order.
Stacks support linear-time parentheses matching by pushing opening symbols and checking corresponding closing symbols.
A queue is a FIFO container with enqueue at the rear, dequeue and front at the front, and supports size and empty.
The STL queue is a templated adapter (typically over vector) providing push, pop, front, back, size, and empty with undefined behavior on empty access.
An array-based queue uses a circular array with indices f and r and count n to achieve O(1) enqueue and dequeue.
A linked-list queue can be implemented with a circularly linked list using a cursor where front is cursor->next and rear is cursor, providing O(1) operations.
A deque supports insertion and removal at both front and back with operations insertFront, insertBack, eraseFront, eraseBack, front, back, size, and empty.
The STL deque is a templated container supporting push_front, push_back, pop_front, pop_back, front, back, size, and empty with undefined behavior on empty access.
A deque can be implemented with a doubly linked list with header and trailer sentinels to provide O(1) time for all deque operations.
An adapter translates one interface to another, allowing stacks and queues to be implemented over a deque by mapping their operations to deque operations.

reinforcement.exercise_content: Describe how to implement a capacity-limited stack, which uses the functions of a capacity-limited deque to perform the functions of the stack ADT in ways that do not throw exceptions when we attempt to perform a push on a full stack or a pop on an empty stack.

Describe how to implement a capacity-limited queue, which uses the functions of a capacity-limited deque to perform the functions of the queue ADT in ways that do not throw exceptions when we attempt to perform a enqueue on a full queue or a dequeue on an empty queue.

Suppose an initially empty stack S has performed a total of 25 push operations, 12 top operations, and 10 pop operations, 3 of which generated a StackEmpty exception that was caught and ignored; what is the current size of S?
If we implemented the stack S from the previous problem with an array as described in this chapter, then what is the current value of the top member variable?

Describe the output of the following series of stack operations: push(5), push(3), pop(), push(2), push(8), pop(), pop(), push(9), push(1), pop(), push(7), push(6), pop(), pop(), push(4), pop(), pop().
Give a recursive function for removing all the elements in a stack.
Modify the stack ADT implementation of Section 5.1.5 as a fully generic class (through the use of templates).
Give a precise and complete definition of the concept of matching for grouping symbols in an arithmetic expression.

Describe the output for the following sequence of queue operations: enqueue(5), enqueue(3), dequeue(), enqueue(2), enqueue(8), dequeue(), dequeue(), enqueue(9), enqueue(1), dequeue(), enqueue(7), enqueue(6), dequeue(), dequeue(), enqueue(4), dequeue(), dequeue().

Describe the output for the following sequence of deque operations: insertFront(3), insertBack(8), insertBack(9), insertFront(5), removeFront(), eraseBack(), first(), insertBack(7), removeFront(), last(), eraseBack().

Suppose you have a deque D containing the numbers (1,2,3,4,5,6,7,8) in this order and an initially empty queue Q; give a pseudo-code description of a function that uses only D and Q and results in D storing the elements (1,2,3,5,4,6,7,8) in this order.
Repeat the previous problem using the deque D and an initially empty stack S.

creativity.exercise_content: Explain how you can implement all the functions of the deque ADT using two stacks.

Suppose you have a stack S containing n elements and a queue Q that is initially empty; describe how you can use Q to scan S to see if it contains a certain element x, with the constraint that the elements must be returned to S in their original order and only S, Q, and a constant number of references may be used.
Give a pseudo-code description for an array-based implementation of the deque ADT and state the running time for each operation.

Suppose Alice has picked three distinct integers and placed them into a stack S in random order; write straight-line pseudo-code using only one comparison and one variable x that guarantees with probability 2/3 that x stores the largest integer, and argue correctness.
Describe how to implement the stack ADT using two queues and analyze the running time of push and pop.
Show how to use an array-based stack S storing (i,j,k) triples to simulate an uninitialized n√ón integer array A so an O(n) algorithm can run without initializing A.
Describe a non-recursive algorithm for enumerating all permutations of the numbers {1,2,...,n}.
Describe a non-recursive way of evaluating an arithmetic expression in postfix notation.
Suppose you have two nonempty stacks S and T and a deque D; describe how to use D so that S contains all elements of T below its original elements, preserving both orders.

Given three array-based stacks A (capacity 100, initially full), B (capacity 5), and C (capacity 3) with only transfer(S,T) available, describe a sequence of transfers resulting in B holding 4 elements.
Show how to use a stack S and a queue Q to generate all possible subsets of an n-element set T non-recursively.

projects.exercise_content: Give an implementation of the deque ADT using an array so that each update function runs in O(1) time.
Design an ADT for a two-color, double-stack with red and blue stacks and implement it efficiently using a single array of capacity N larger than the combined sizes.
Implement the stack ADT in a fully generic manner using a singly linked list without using the STL or earlier structures.
Implement the stack ADT in a fully generic manner using the STL vector class.
Implement the queue ADT in a fully generic manner using a dynamically allocated C++ array.
Implement the queue ADT with a singly linked list.
Implement the deque ADT with an array used in a circular fashion.
Implement the deque ADT with a doubly linked list.
Implement a capacity-limited version of the deque ADT based on an array used in a circular fashion.
Implement the Stack and Queue interfaces with a unique class derived from class LinkedDeque.
Write a program that computes total capital gain or loss from a sequence of stock buy and sell transactions using the FIFO protocol.
Implement a program that inputs a postfix expression and outputs its value.
